problem.tex: Let $\gamma(t)=e^{it}$ for $0\leq t\leq2\pi$. Evaluate \[\int_\gamma\ln\left(\frac{z-2i}{z+2i}\right)dz.\] You will need to specify your branch of log.

solution.tex: We want to see where $\gamma$ goes under the Mobius transformation $\frac{z-2i}{z+2i}$. To do this, map a few points. $\gamma$ follows $1\mapsto i\mapsto-1\mapsto-i\mapsto1$, this becomes \[-\frac{3}{5}-\frac{4}{5}i\mapsto-\frac{1}{3}\mapsto-\frac{3}{5}+\frac{4}{5}i\mapsto-3\mapsto-\frac{3}{5}-\frac{4}{5}i\] Note the pole occurs at $-2i$, outside the region encircled by $\gamma$. Regardless of our branch of log, it will always be holomorphic if it can be defined. If we define our branch of log for $\theta\in(0,2\pi)$ then our branch is defined on the interior of the image of $\gamma$, so by Cauchy's integral theorem the integral vanishes.
